steps.title: On the receiving end of a big head joke? Hereâ€™s what to say back!
steps.content: On the receiving end of a big head joke? Hereâ€™s what to say back! Anyone who dishes a big head joke better be prepared for a taste of their own medicine, and we can help with that too! Whether you want to turn an insult about having a big head into a compliment, prove you can take a joke yourself, or throw back an equally clever and scathing remark, respond with these witty comebacks: Insult: Youâ€™ve got a huge head! steps.title: Save insulting jokes for audiences youâ€™re confident will appreciate them.
steps.content: Save insulting jokes for audiences youâ€™re confident will appreciate them. Hey, not everyone likes to have it pointed out how big their head is. And thatâ€™s understandable! These jokes are funny, but not if the person youâ€™re telling them to is sensitive about their appearance. If you donâ€™t know the person youâ€™re making fun of well, or if you suspect they wouldnâ€™t appreciate a joke at their expense, zip it.

steps.title: Target yourself in addition to (or instead of) others.
steps.content: Target yourself in addition to (or instead of) others. Self-deprecating humor is a great way to joke around while ensuring youâ€™re not hurting anyoneâ€™s feelings. Or, if you want to rib some of your good buddies, even the score by also making fun of yourself: itâ€™ll show them youâ€™re all on the same level, and that youâ€™re not punching down so much as punching across. steps.title: If you want to dish it, be sure you can take it.
steps.content: If you want to dish it, be sure you can take it. Jokes at other peopleâ€™s expense may or may not get you into hot water, but nobody wants to hear cracks from someone who canâ€™t gracefully receive them in return. If youâ€™re prepared to dish it out, be ready for a taste of your own medicine.

steps.title: Be sensitive to how your jokes are received and apologize if needed.
steps.content: Be sensitive to how your jokes are received and apologize if needed. Keep an eye out for how people are taking your jokes: even if nobody says, â€œHey, knock it off,â€ their body language can tell you a lot about whether theyâ€™re really enjoying what youâ€™re saying or if theyâ€™re silently tolerating it. Does their smile seem genuine? You can tell if a smile is genuine if it reaches the eyes: a real smile engages the whole face, including the eyes, while a fake smile usually only engages the mouth muscles. Is their posture open and relaxed? A person whoâ€™s genuinely having a good time will likely display a more relaxed, loose posture with their arms out or by their sides, while a person whoâ€™s uncomfortable will likely seem more physically closed off, with arms crossed, shoulders hunched, and body turned away from you. [3] X Research source If someone does seem offended or voices discomfort, be gracious and empathetic, and back off immediately. Apologize sincerely, and let them know you wonâ€™t make the same jokes in the future: â€œIâ€™m so sorry, I was messing around, but I took it too far. I wonâ€™t make these jokes anymore.â€
